ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I practiced conceptual art and learned how to think more deeply about the materials and composition of my work.
Learned new ways to think about my art process.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I enjoyed the balance of speakers, studio times, critiques, check ins, and class exercises. The only thing that could be improved is if this class was in person.
Enjoyed the supportive atmosphere and creative freedom. Good in-class activities.
Good instruction and fun lectures. Online studio classes were not ideal for making art.

Although the critiques were very helpful, I felt that we did not spend much time talking about painting techniques, and I sometimes felt that I was urged to try other media. I do like to try different media in my personal practice, but I sometimes found it difficult to receive clear feedback from my class about painting-specific techniques, which was my primary motivation for taking the course.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Because of the zoom format, I think it was difficult to get informal input from my peers or engage in more casual conversations. Check ins were easy with screen sharing and it was nice to talk to artists over zoom.
The small size of the class allowed it to feel almost like an in-person seminar.
Could use more engaging studio time.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to incorporate painting into their daily practice and engage in conversations with interesting and talented people.
Yes, if you want a very open-ended painting class. Lots of freedom to pursue your interests.

I would still recommend the course to another student, especially since more students at Yale seem to be fine arts-focused, rather than design- or illustration-focused. I would explain that representational, two-dimensional work is not really the primary focus, but the class still gave enough space for me to do what I wanted. I just did not always receive the most clear feedback.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
